attr.complications: muscle weakness, skin issues, increased susceptibility to infections

reference: Hyperadrenocorticism, also known as Cushing's disease, is a common endocrine disorder in companion animals, particularly in middle-aged to older dogs. - https://www.scielo.br/j/pvb/a/7YjhBgRry38Cb89BDMWWbxx/?lang=en

The clinical signs of Cushing's disease in both dogs and cats include increased thirst, increased urination, increased appetite, weight loss, muscle wasting, a pot-bellied appearance, thin skin, and hair loss. - https://www.aaha.org/resources/2023-aaha-selected-endocrinopathies-of-dogs-and-cats-guidelines/feline-hyperadrenocorticismhypercortisolism/

Hyperadrenocorticism, also known as Cushing's disease, is a condition in pets characterized by excessive production of the hormone cortisol. The most common clinical signs include increased thirst and urination, increased appetite, weight gain, muscle weakness, lethargy, and thinning of the skin - https://www.merckvetmanual.com/endocrine-system/the-pituitary-gland/cushing-disease-pituitary-dependent-hyperadrenocorticism-in-animals
In some cases, dogs may experience alopecia (hair loss) and fragile skin that bruises easily - https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/treating-cushings-disease-dogs
This condition is characterized by excessive production of cortisol, a hormone produced by the adrenal glands. - https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6500859/

In the majority of cases, hyperadrenocorticism is caused by a tumor in the pituitary gland that secretes excessive amounts of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). - Cushing's Disease in Dogs (Hyperadrenocorticism): What Is It? https://veterinarypartner.vin.com/default.aspx?pid=19239&catId=254094&id=4951983

Screening and diagnostic tests are used to confirm the diagnosis. These may include the urine cortisol-to-creatinine ratio, low-dose dexamethasone suppression test, and ACTH stimulation test - The Diagnosis of Canine Hyperadrenocorticism: https://todaysveterinarypractice.com/endocrinology/the-diagnosis-of-canine-hyperadrenocorticism/

Screening and diagnostic tests are used to confirm the diagnosis. These may include the urine cortisol-to-creatinine ratio, low-dose dexamethasone suppression test, and ACTH stimulation test - The Diagnosis of Canine Hyperadrenocorticism: https://todaysveterinarypractice.com/endocrinology/the-diagnosis-of-canine-hyperadrenocorticism/

attr.limitations: cannot differentiate between pituitary and adrenal forms

reference: Screening and diagnostic tests are used to confirm the diagnosis. These may include the urine cortisol-to-creatinine ratio, low-dose dexamethasone suppression test, and ACTH stimulation test - The Diagnosis of Canine Hyperadrenocorticism: https://todaysveterinarypractice.com/endocrinology/the-diagnosis-of-canine-hyperadrenocorticism/
The primary treatment for hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease) in dogs is medical management with mitotane (op'-DDD; Lysodren) - Treatment of Canine Hyperadrenocorticism - WSAVA2011 - VIN
Trilostane is also a commonly used medication for treating hyperadrenocorticism in both dogs and cats - Feline Hyperadrenocorticism/Hypercortisolism - AAHA
Melatonin has also been used as a first-line treatment, especially for cases with alopecia, as it has few side effects - Treatment Considerations - University of Tennessee

attr.risks: adrenal insufficiency if done too quickly

reference: For iatrogenic hyperadrenocorticism caused by exogenous corticosteroid administration, the treatment involves a gradual, controlled withdrawal of the offending drug - Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's Disease) - International Cat Care

Other causes of polyuria and polydipsia, such as diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, or psychogenic polydipsia - Diagnosing canine hyperadrenocorticism (Proceedings) - DVM360: https://www.dvm360.com/view/diagnosing-canine-hyperadrenocorticism-proceedings

Additionally, skin conditions like demodicosis, dermatophytosis, or allergic skin disease can cause similar changes in the skin and coat as seen in Cushing's disease - Cushing's Disease in Dogs | VCA Animal Hospitals: https://vcahospitals.com/know-your-pet/cushings-disease-in-dogs

Additionally, skin conditions like demodicosis, dermatophytosis, or allergic skin disease can cause similar changes in the skin and coat as seen in Cushing's disease - Cushing's Disease in Dogs | VCA Animal Hospitals: https://vcahospitals.com/know-your-pet/cushings-disease-in-dogs

In the majority of cases, hyperadrenocorticism is caused by a tumor in the pituitary gland that secretes excessive amounts of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). - Cushing's Disease in Dogs (Hyperadrenocorticism): What Is It? https://veterinarypartner.vin.com/default.aspx?pid=19239&catId=254094&id=4951983

Alternatively, in a smaller percentage of cases, hyperadrenocorticism can be caused by a tumor directly in one of the adrenal glands. - Cushings Disease in Cats | VCA Animal Hospitals https://vcahospitals.com/know-your-pet/cushings-disease-in-cats
